description: Explore the elements of the periodic table, metals, acids, and coordination complexes.

slides.title: What is Inorganic Chemistry?
slides.content:
# Beyond Carbon üíé

Inorganic chemistry covers the properties and behavior of inorganic compounds‚Äîwhich allow for minerals, metals, and organometallic compounds.

Basically, **everything except standard carbon-chain biology stuff**.

Applications: Catalysts, coatings, fuels, surfactants, materials, superconductors, and drugs.

slides.title: The Periodic Table
slides.content:
# The Chemist's Map üó∫Ô∏è

Organized by Atomic Number ($Z$) and electron configuration.

- **Groups (Columns)**: Similar valence electrons $\to$ Similar properties.
- **Periods (Rows)**: Adding electron shells.

Key Groups:
- 1: Alkali Metals (Explosive with water)
- 17: Halogens (Reactive non-metals)
- 18: Noble Gases (Inert)

slides.title: Periodic Trends: Size
slides.content:
# Atomic Radius ‚≠ï

- **Down a Group**: Increases (Adding shells).
- **Across a Period**: Decreases (More protons pull electrons tighter).

Francium is huge; Helium is tiny.

slides.title: Periodic Trends: Energy
slides.content:
# Holding on ‚ö°

**Ionization Energy**: Energy needed to remove an electron.
- Increases up and to the right.

**Electronegativity**: Ability to attract electrons in a bond.
- Fluorine is the bully (most electronegative).
- Francium is the giver (least).

slides.title: Trends Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which element has the highest electronegativity?

slides.title: Acids and Bases
slides.content:
# Proton Wars üçãüßº

**Bronsted-Lowry Definition:**
- **Acid**: Proton ($H^+$) Donor.
- **Base**: Proton ($H^+$) Acceptor.

**Lewis Definition:**
- **Acid**: Electron pair acceptor.
- **Base**: Electron pair donor.

slides.title: pH Scale
slides.content:
# Power of Hydrogen üìâ

Measure of acidity.
$$pH = -\log[H^+]$$

- **< 7**: Acidic (Lemon, Stomach acid)
- **7**: Neutral (Water)
- **> 7**: Basic (Soap, Bleach)

Logarithmic scale: pH 3 is 10x more acidic than pH 4.

slides.title: Salts
slides.content:
# Neutralization üßÇ

Acid + Base $\to$ Salt + Water

$$HCl + NaOH \to NaCl + H_2O$$

Salts are ionic compounds composed of related numbers of cations and anions so that the product is electrically neutral.

slides.title: Redox Reactions
slides.content:
# Moving Electrons üîã

**Red**uction-**Ox**idation reactions.

- **Oxidation**: Loss of electrons (OIL).
- **Reduction**: Gain of electrons (RIG).

$$Zn + Cu^{2+} \to Zn^{2+} + Cu$$

Zinc is oxidized (loses e-), Copper is reduced (gains e-).

slides.title: Oxidation States
slides.content:
# Bookkeeping üìö

Hypothetical charge an atom would have if all bonds were ionic.

Rules:
- Pure elements = 0 ($O_2, Fe$)
- Fluorine = -1
- Oxygen = -2 (usually)
- Sum adds up to molecule's charge.

slides.title: Coordination Compounds
slides.content:
# Metal Complexes üèóÔ∏è

A central metal atom/ion bonded to surrounding molecules or anions (**Ligands**).

- **Coordination Number**: bonds to central atom.
- Example: Hemoglobin (Iron complex), Chlorophyll (Magnesium complex).
- Often vividly colored!

slides.title: Crystal Field Theory
slides.content:
# Colors of Gems üíé

Explains colors and magnetism of coordination complexes.

- Ligands split the d-orbital energies of the metal.
- Electrons jumping between these split levels absorb light.
- The unabsorbed light is the color we see (e.g., Ruby = Chromium).

slides.title: Main Group Elements
slides.content:
# The Standard Blocks üß±

S and P block elements.
- **Alkali Metals**: Very reactive.
- **Alkaline Earth Metals**: Magnesium, Calcium.
- **Nitrogen/Phosphorus**: Essential for life (DNA, Fertilizer).
- **Sulfur**: Cross-links proteins.

slides.title: Transition Metals
slides.content:
# The D-Block ‚öôÔ∏è

Groups 3-12.
- Variable oxidation states ($Fe^{2+}, Fe^{3+}$).
- Form colored compounds.
- Good catalysts.
- Magnetic properties (Iron, Cobalt, Nickel).

slides.title: Bioinorganic Chemistry
slides.content:
# Metals in Life üåø

Life isn't just organic!
- **Iron**: Oxygen transport in blood.
- **Calcium**: Bones and signaling.
- **Zinc**: Enzyme function.
- **Sodium/Potassium**: Nerve impulses.

slides.title: Industrial Inorganic Chem
slides.content:
# Big Scale üè≠

- **Sulfuric Acid ($H_2SO_4$)**: #1 chemical produced globally (Fertilizer, refining).
- **Ammonia ($NH_3$)**: Haber process (Fertilizer).
- **Chlorine**: Sanitation and plastics.

slides.title: Nanomaterials
slides.content:
# Tiny Chemistry üî¨

Inorganic materials at the nanoscale (1-100 nm).
- Quantum Dots (TV displays).
- Gold nanoparticles (Medicine).
- Carbon Nanotubes (Super strong materials).

slides.title: Inorganic Chemistry Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **Periodic Trends** guide reactivity.
- **Acids/Bases** and **Redox** are key reaction types.
- **Transition Metals** create colorful complexes and catalyze reactions.
- Inorganic chemistry powers industry, technology, and biology.
